journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Systematic gear shift model for an automatic-transmission-based parallel hybrid electric vehicle

contrib-group.aff: School of Automotive Engineering, Kyungpook National University, Gyungbuk, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Gi-Woo Kim, School of Automotive Engineering, Kyungpook National University, 2559 Gyeongsang-daero, Sangju, Gyungbuk 742-711, Republic of Korea. Email: gwkim2@knu.ac.kr

abstract.p: This paper presents a new systematic gear shift modelling approach for the real-time powertrain control and simulation of a multi-stepped automatic-transmission-based powertrain system such as parallel-type hybrid electric vehicles. The power/on 1 → 2 upshift modelling of a six-speed automatic transmision which is the main element of a Lepelletier-type planetary gear set is first performed to illustrate the procedure of the proposed gear shift modelling. A condensed algebraic formulation of the gear shift for each state is derived for a computationally efficient calculation based on the system matrix obtained from all governing equations. Finally, a non-linear shift simulation and brief open-loop shift control using MATLAB/Stateflow® are performed to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed gear shift model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The development of a control-oriented powertrain model has been studied by numerous researchers since the introduction of closed-loop control systems in automotive vehicles.1 Of all the components of powertrain models, a dynamic gear shift model of transmission, especially an automatic transmission (AT), is essential to simulate the overall powertrain model and to design a model-based feedback controller, and hence modelling efforts have been directed towards formulating a gear shift model for automotive transmissions. It is, however, extremely difficult to derive a simple but systematic gear shift model since the gear shift dynamic system is one of the most complicated dynamic systems (frequently called a state transition system).2 Consequently, a detailed gear shift model is often assumed to be neglected because of the lack of modelling knowledge in most research on the development of powertrain simulation and control models. For instance, a simple gear shift model using gear ratios is currently utilized although the AT-based parallel-type hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) illustrated in Figure 1 has recently been receiving growing attention in the automotive industry as one of the most promising alternatives to conventional powertrains.3 The gear shift dynamics for AT shift simulation and control have been modelled using various methods, such as lever analogy diagrams,4 the bond graph method5,6 and the finite element method.7 The lever analogy method is still widely used in formulating an output torque equation for shift controller designs because of its simplicity.8 The main advantage of the bond graph method is the convenience of dealing with redundant state variables. The major benefit of the finite element method is that it can handle more state variables such as angular displacements and the effect of the shaft stiffness. Some researchers have focused on the development of a shift model based on direct solution of the governing equations.9,10 On the other hand, numerous object-oriented graphical-user-interface-based simulation software packages such as AMESim®, EASY5®, SimDrivelineTM, and Advanced Vehicle Simulator (ADVISOR) have been developed recently for the modelling and analysis of advanced powertrain systems. It is, however, necessary to build a complete gear shift model since the aforementioned simulation tools do not provide the dynamic transient phenomenon during a gear shift as well as sufficient information for designing a shift controller, as illustrated in Figure 2(a), although they have been successfully validated in evaluating vehicle performance such as the fuel consumption. In fact, the real-world gear shift can be characterized by a series of consecutive stages (i.e. offgoing gear, torque phase, inertia phase and oncoming gear) from the experimental test result, as shown in Figure 2(b). In addition, from the viewpoint of the simulation efficiency, the gear shift model has to be as simple as possible for the hardware-in-the-loop simulation (HILS) used in the development of real-time embedded vehicle systems since the simulation of an HEV is more time consuming because an HEV has more electrical parts and a more complicated electrochemical battery model than a conventional vehicle has. To this end, we can directly formulate the system’s governing equations as condensed-solution equations such as the output torque equation.11 However, it is challenging to derive manually the complete solution equations with an increasing number of gear steps in the AT (i.e. above seven speeds).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of an AT-based parallel-type HEV.
Comparison result of the 1 → 2 upshift of the AT: (a) simulation using commercial software; (b) real-world gear-shifting behaviour.

sec.p: The primary objective of this study is therefore to develop a systematic (easy to formulate) and computationally efficient gear shift modelling method for advanced powertrain systems equipped with a multi-stepped AT. To illustrate the systematic procedure of the proposed method, the power/on 1 → 2 upshift model of a six-speed AT which is the main element of a Lepelletier-type planetary gear set is first formulated in the second section. The condensed-equation sets for shift simulation are then computationally derived by using a reduced-row echelon matrix form. The non-linear simulation of the power/on 1 → 2 upshift model and the conceptual shift control of an AT-based HEV using the motor torque are performed to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed modelling approach using a series of algebraic condensed equations derived in the third section.

sec.title: Formulation of 1→2 gear shift model
sec.p: In this study, the power/on 1 → 2 upshift model of a six-speed AT, which is the main component of a Lepelletier-type planetary gear set, is first formulated to illustrate the systematic gear shift modelling method. A schematic diagram of the Lepelletier-type planetary-gear-based six-speed AT is illustrated in Figure 3.12 The planetary gear set is the combination of a simple planetary gear set and a Ravigneaux gear (RG) set. To drive the rear RG set, this design uses a front simple gear set, which serves as a reduced-speed input and reverse gears. The input shaft is directly connected to the first ring gear R1 of a simple planetary gear set. The first sun gear S1 of the simple planetary gear is rigidly mounted on to the housing of an AT case. The mount torque TM is accordingly present in this transmission layout. An oncoming friction element, brake D, is connected to the carrier C2C3 of an RG. An offgoing friction element, brake C, is also connected to the second sun gear S2 of the RG.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the friction elements and Lepelletier-type planetary gear set.12

Additionally, because clutch A is already engaged while in the driving position, the angular acceleration of the carrier gear C1 of the simple planetary gear set will be constrained by the third sun gear S3 of the RG set according to

mml:mrow.mml:mtext: in the first gear and torque phase

sec.p:
In the case of other gear shifts (e.g. the 2 → 3 upshift), these constraints become different according to the friction element hook-up (engagement) table. The four state variables of primary interest are typically the input acceleration, the output acceleration, the output torque and the friction element torques in the gear shift modelling. On the basis of the governing equation sets, it is well known that these important four state variables can be derived in terms of the input torque
T
I
and friction element torques
T
C
and
T
D
, which are frequently referred to as the condensed shift equations. In this section, all coefficients required for the 1 → 2 upshift are numerically formulated through matrix manipulation, instead of manual derivation. The governing equations for the first gear and torque phase (i.e. equation (1) together with equation (20)) can be explicitly expressed by the matrix form
where

As noted, the number of linear equations (i.e. 20 rows) is less than the number of unknown variables (i.e. 22 columns), which can be characterized by an undetermined problem. Additionally, equation set (21) is called a homogeneous simultaneous equation (frequently referred to as null space in linear algebra). Accordingly, a unique solution is not possible. In general, if the set of vectors is linearly independent, then the set of vectors is called a basis for the vector space. Typically, the solution to equation (21) can be written as a linear combination of basis vectors. In other words, it is possible to express the solution in terms of independent variables, which can be any real number. Fortunately, the input torque from the engine side and friction element torques are independent variables since they can be a time-varying known input controlled by throttle opening or the applied pressure. Unlike the state space equation commonly used in dynamic system modelling, this approach does not require first-order differential equation sets and is a more convenient method than a general method using state–space equations because it allows the use of torque equations including constraint equations, which is essential for analysing a gear shift model.

caption.p: Flow chart for power/on 1 → 2 upshift simulation.

sec.title: Gear shift simulation
sec.p: As described in the second section, gear shift dynamics can be characterized by the state transition system and consist of a series of condensed-solution equations. However, all variables derived for each gear and phase should be continuous over the entire gear shift. In this study, a non-linear simulation is performed to validate the continuity of the variables of interest and the effectiveness of the proposed modelling approach. The generation of independent torques is then required to perform the non-linear simulation of the power/on 1 → 2 upshift.

sec.title: Friction element torque
sec.p:
Although the dynamic friction element model is required to capture an accurate temperature-dependent shifting characteristic, a heuristic algebraic model is sufficient for generation of the friction element torques under normal test conditions. The linear relationship between the torque capacities TCf and TDf of two wet-type brakes and the applied net actuation force
F
n
can be expressed by

where

) acts as the proportional gain, which is approximately estimated to be 0.8 in this study. The applied net actuation force
F
n
can be calculated from the actuation pressure applied to the piston of the hydraulic cylinder built inside the brakes (e.g. φ = 0.05 m) and the return spring force (assumed to be negligible). During the slipping, the oncoming and offgoing friction element torques should be determined by the direction of the connected rotational elements according to

sec.title: Simulation results and discussion
sec.p:
The use of the state chart modelling technique can reflect the aforementioned inherent nature of the AT in which each gear and phase include the condensed governing equations.14 It is suitable to describe state transition systems such as AT gear shift dynamics owing to their hierarchical approach for expressing the complex dynamic behaviour. Based on this modelling frame and new approach, the power/on 1 → 2 upshift model can be easily represented by the state chart and implemented by the commercial package MATLAB® with the Stateflow Toolbox.15Figure 5 shows the block diagram of the simulation model implemented by Stateflow®. Only four velocity states of interest (e.g.
ω
I
,
ω
O
,
ω
C 2 C 3
and
ω
S 2
) are finally calculated by numerically integrating their angular accelerations. The fourth-order Runge–Kutta method with a step size of 0.0001 s is used for the numerical integration algorithm. This simulation structure also allows us to avoid the calculation burden for unnecessary variables such as the angular acceleration of the internal planetary gear sets. Additionally, it is unnecessary to perform a matrix operation such as calculation of the inverse matrix since all coefficients described in the third section are a priori knowledge that will be determined through offline calculation, leading to extremely fast central processsing unit executing times. Therefore, the use of condensed-solution equations for the shift model allows a significant alleviation of computing effort, which is suitable for implementing a shift controller on the transmission control unit and real-time HILSs.11

caption.p: Sub-block diagram of the power/on 1 → 2 upshift simulation model.

sec.p:
A typical non-linear simulation result is presented in Figure 6. The start of the 1 → 2 upshift is scheduled when the output speed
ω
O
reaches a prescribed value in the shift pattern (in this example, around 20.5 s). The two pressure profiles for the actuation of oncoming and offgoing friction elements are determined on the basis of the general clutch-to-clutch shift control strategy.16 At the onset of the torque phase, the output torque drops (frequently referred to as the torque hole) since a part of the input torque is re-routed through the oncoming friction element. The inertia phase is characterized by a sudden increase in the transient output torque caused by the gear ratio change within a very short period of time, in general 0.5 s, and by the deceleration of the engine speed. The engine speed and the input shaft speed have nearly the same values owing to the rigidity of the input shaft (i.e. the relatively large torsional spring constant). However, the output vehicle speed will gradually increase owing to the relatively larger inertia of the vehicle. The transient output torque eventually decreases to the second gear torque level in the second gear state. As observed, the proposed 1 → 2 upshift model captures all the important shift characteristics illustrated in Figure 2(b). The four variables of interest also are continuous without the jump phenomenon, which implies that all the derived coefficients turn out to be appropriate.

caption.p: Simulation result of the power/on 1 → 2 upshift: (a) the engine speed (—), the input speed (····) and the output (vehicle) speed (- - - -); (b) the output torque (—), the oncoming friction element pressure (···) and the offgoing friction element pressure (- - - -).

sec.p: To illustrate further the effectiveness of the proposed gear shift modelling method, a conceptual and simple shift controller for enhanced shift performance (e.g. shift quality) is introduced on the basis of the derived shift model. A conventional torque converter is typically replaced with an electric motor and a combustion engine connecting the clutch in the AT-based HEV, as shown in Figure 1. As a result, it is important to control the shift quality since it does not provide the fluid damping effect induced by the conventional torque converter. A recent analysis has shown that the transmission gear shift performance can be improved during the upshift by simply adding a brief input torque (e.g. an engine torque) modulation scheme,17,18 as well as an optimized clutch-to-clutch control strategy.16 The alternative approach for an AT-based parallel HEV has recently been studied using electric motor speed control, instead of engine torque control, because the control response of most electric motors is much faster than that of an engine.19 With the idea of modulating the input torque, we can readily design a simple open-loop shift controller based on the proposed gear shift model. For instance, the amount of the electric motor torque for the smooth output torque during the torque phase can be determined from equation (25) according to

where
T
EM
is the electric motor torque to be transmitted to the output shaft of a transmission. Note that the oncoming friction element torque
T
C
in equation (39) can be calculated from the prescribed pressure profile of the oncoming clutch (see Figure 6(b)) and is negative because the rotation direction of the second sun gear is opposite to that of the first ring gear (defined as the positive direction). In order to offset the variation in the oncoming friction element torque
T
C
induced by the varying actuation force (i.e. the oncoming clutch pressure), the motor torque required is

During the inertia phase, the input torque can also be reduced by simply adding the negative motor torque to alleviate the increase in the transient output torque produced by the change in the acceleration of transmission components according to
Then, the electric motor torque can be roughly designed using

Unlike the torque phase control (i.e. equation (40)), the coefficient of 0.9 is empirically adjusted to compensate the unknown input torque
T
C
in this study. A typical simulation result for shift control with the open-loop controller (i.e. equations (40) and (42)) is presented in Figure 7. The most common shift quality evaluation index, namely the vibration dose value (VDV), is introduced to evaluate the shift quality20 and is given by

caption.p: Simulation result of the power/on 1 → 2 upshift control: (a) the output torque with motor control (—) and the output torque without motor control (- - - -); (b) the commanded motor torque.

sec.p: Once the motor torque is produced as shown in Figure 7(b), the torque hole around 20.5 s is filled and the magnitude of the maximum output torque is also decreased, which will lead to an improvement in the shift quality. The VDV defined in equation (43) is accordingly reduced from 641 to 291 during the time period between 20.5 s and 21.5 s. This motor torque profile shows the same pattern as the engine torque modulation profile.15 From this simulation result, it is demonstrated that a gear shift model-based ad hoc open-loop shift controller can be built. Although it is challenging to detect the end (or start) point of each phase during the shift, this simple shift control approach derived from the system governing equations can provide the fundamental information for designing a shift controller for multi-stepped AT-based powertrain systems such as parallel-type HEVs. Based on this brief open-loop control scheme, the elaborate integrated powertrain control will smooth the sharp transition behaviour.16

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: A new systematic approach for AT gear shift modelling is presented on the basis of the inherent mathematical property of AT gear shift dynamics (undetermined problem). The formulation of condensed-solution equations through the reduced-row echelon matrix form is capable of modelling any AT gear shift dynamics by carefully handling the system’s governing equations for planetary gear sets. The simulation results show that it is possible to express the solutions in terms of the time-varying independent torques. The use of this approach allows a marked acceleration of computing efficiency, which is suitable for the HILS implementation of a parallel-type HEV. The proposed modelling method also appears to offer a basic algorithm for the development of advanced powertrain simulation software and controller design.
